Crimes.Crime_Name: Obstruction of justice (refusal to clean net before measurement)
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the enforcement officer act lawfully in seizing the net based on micrometer measurements without cleaning it first?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Officer measured the net using a micrometer and found it exceeded allowable limits; applicant argued net should have been cleaned first, but no legal requirement for cleaning was established.
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Challenge to seizure of fishing gear
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Refused to clean net prior to measurement
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged procedural impropriety in measurement process
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of enforcement action under statutory authority
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Validity of micrometer measurement without prior cleaning
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Micrometer reading showing excessive filament size
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Return of seized net and invalidation of seizure
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Officers may seize fishing gear if believed to violate regulations
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence that cleaning is required by regulation
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: None established – lawful exercise of authority
Crimes.Cause_Description: Fisherman used a net exceeding filament size limits; enforcement policy changed to stricter measures
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Measurement conducted in field with calibrated micrometer
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Fisheries Act regulations on net filament size
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Dispute over necessity of cleaning before measurement
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Micrometer method accepted as valid standard
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No regulatory requirement to clean net before measurement; officer acted within lawful discretion
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Applicant's claim about cleaning not supported by regulation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with Fisheries Act regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the enforcement officer exceed his authority by seizing the applicant's gill net under the new policy?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Net measured 94 microns, exceeding 80-micron limit; Minister implemented stricter enforcement policy; officer acted within statutory discretion.
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Invalidation of seizure and return of gear
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Possession and use of oversized filament net
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation that enforcement policy improperly removed officer discretion
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Whether policy directive overrides individual officer judgment
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lawfulness of seizure under updated enforcement directives
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Micrometer measurement, regulatory records, policy documentation
Crimes.Application_Basis: Use of gear violating denier/micron limits
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of seizure and policy
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Officers may seize gear used in connection with an offense
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Regulatory breach posed risk to sustainable fisheries
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicant used a gill net exceeding filament size limits, leading to its seizure
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: PCSF Regulations s. 26(1) – filament size limit
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: None raised regarding accuracy or calibration
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Measurements reliable and consistent with standards
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Clear regulatory violation; policy does not negate statutory discretion

Crimes.Crime_Name: Unlawful fishing with prohibited gill net
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the enforcement officer act within his authority by seizing a gill net exceeding filament size limits under s. 26 of the PCSF Regulations?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Fisheries Act, s. 58; Pacific Commercial Salmon Fisheries (PCSF) Regulations, s. 26
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Micrometer measurement confirmed excess filament size
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show unlawful seizure
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Officers may seize gear used in commission of a regulatory offense
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Validity of field measurement and seizure protocol
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Challenge to legality of seizure and enforcement policy
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Micrometer readings, expert testimony on measurement standards
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Fisheries Act, s. 58; PCSF Regs s. 26
Crimes.Applicable_Process: Administrative seizure followed by judicial review
Crimes.Pending_Relief_or_Application: Application for return of gear dismissed
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Seizure authorized where gear violates size regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of fishing gear used in commission of an offence
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the enforcement officer exceed his authority by seizing a gill net based on micrometer measurements under the Fisheries Act?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Micrometer measurement and expert testimony confirmed violation
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Technical evidence relied upon was objective
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Officers may seize gear used in committing a regulatory offense
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Legality of seizure based on field measurement
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation that policy eliminated officer discretion
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Micrometer results, expert analysis, policy documents
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Contested validity of enforcement policy and measurement method
Crimes.Court_Result: Application dismissed; costs awarded to Minister
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Seizure lawful under statute and policy
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Invalidation of seizure and return of gear
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Possession of gear violating filament size limits
Crimes.Applicable_Process: Administrative seizure with right to judicial review
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Authorized seizure of gear used in offense
